the pressure of liquids in equilibrium; the pressure exerted by or within liquids.
any of an order of highly specialized insects such as bees and wasps.

excessive pressure of carbon dioxide in the blood.

stage of the burn process in which there is increased body metabolism in an attempt by the body to heal the burn.
a solution that has a concentration of the substance greater than that of a second solution.
an increase in number of cells resulting from an increased workload.
an unexpected and exaggerated reaction to a particular antigen. It is used synonymously with the term allergy.
blood pressure higher than normal.

an acute elevation of blood pressure that requires the blood pressure to be lowered within one hour; characterized by end-organ changes such as hypertensive encephalopathy, renal failure, or blindness.

a cerebral disorder of hypertension indicated by severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and altered mental status. Neurological symptoms may include blindness, muscle twitches, inability to speak, weakness, and paralysis.
unusually high core body temperature.
excessive secretion of thyroid hormones resulting in an increased metabolic rate.
having a greater concentration of solute molecules; one solution may be hypertonic to another.
an increase in the size or bulk of an organ.
blood in the anterior chamber of the eye, in front of the iris.
instigation of sleep.
an abnormal concern with one's health, with the false belief of suffering from some disease, despite medical assurances to the contrary; commonly known as hypochondria.
hollow metal tube used with the syringe to administer medications.
abnormally low concentration of glucose in the blood.
seizure that occurs when brain cells aren't functioning normally due to low blood glucose.
a solution that has a concentration of the substance lower than that of a second solution.
inadequate perfusion of body tissues resulting in inadequate supplies of oxygen and nutrients to body tissue; also called shock.
lower than normal blood pressure.
portion of the diencephalon producing neurosecretions important in the control of certain metabolic activities, including body temperature regulation.

reduced volume in the cardiovascular system.

mechanism that increases respiratory stimulation when PaO2 falls and inhibits respiratory stimulation when PaO2 climbs.
lateral bony ridge that is a landmark of the pelvis.
large, flat innominate bone.

a swiftly occurring secondary hypersensitivity reaction (one that occurs after reexposure to an antigen). Immediate hypersensitivity reactions are usually more severe than delayed reactions. The swiftest and most severe such reaction is anaphylaxis.
the body's reactions that inactivate or eliminate foreign antigens.
diminished vigor of the immune response to the challenge and rechallenge by pathogens.
the body's mechanism for defending against foreign invaders and infection.
a long-term condition of protection from infection or disease; the body's ability to respond to the presence of a pathogen. In law, exemption from legal liability.
antigens that are able to trigger an immune response.
alternative term for antibody.
break in a bone in which the bone is compressed on itself.

condition characterized by the patient's failure to control recurrent impulses.
acting instinctively without stopping to think.
an agent that combusts easily or creates combustion.
a subset of explosives with less explosive power but greater heat and burn potential.
a management program designed for controlling, directing, and coordinating emergency response resources; sometimes used as a synonym for Incident Management System (IMS).
the person responsible for coordinating all activities at a multiple-casualty scene.
very smooth or surgical laceration, frequently caused by a knife, scalpel, razor blade, or piece of glass.
inability to retain urine or feces because of loss of sphincter control or cerebral or spinal lesions.
the time between contact with a disease organism and the appearance of the first symptoms.
the individual who first introduced an infectious agent to a population.
your anticipation of possible injuries based upon your analysis of the event.
immunity achieved through vaccination given to generate an immune response that results in the development of antibodies specific for the injected antigen; also called artificially acquired immunity.
tendency of an object to remain at rest or in motion unless acted upon by an external force.
area of dead tissue caused by lack of blood.
presence of an agent within the host, without necessarily causing disease.
any disease caused by the growth of pathogenic microorganisms, which may be spread from person to person.
presence of parasites that do not break the host's skin.

a nonspecific defense mechanism that wards off damage from microorganisms or trauma.
disease caused by a group of viruses.

consent for treatment that is given based on full disclosure of information.
liquid medication delivered through a vein.

device that delivers fluids and medications under positive pressure.

entry of a substance into the body through the respiratory tract.
prehospital process designed to identify and correct life-threatening airway, breathing, and circulation problems.
placement of medication in or under the skin with a needle and syringe.
intentional or unintentional damage to a person resulting from acute exposure to thermal, mechanical, electrical, or chemical energy or from the absence of such essentials as heat and oxygen.
a real or potentially hazardous situation that puts people in danger of sustaining injury.
the ongoing systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of injury data essential to the planning, implementation, and evaluation of public health practice.
one of the structures of the pelvis.
pertaining to cardiac contractile force.
attachment of a muscle to a bone that moves when the muscle contracts.
the process of informed observation.
physical or emotional violence or neglect when an elder is being cared for by a person paid to provide care.
to blow into.
pancreatic hormone needed to transport simple sugars from the interstitial spaces into the cells.
skin, consisting of the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous layers.
specialized bands of tissue inserted between myocardial cells that increase the rate in which the action potential is spread from cell to cell.
intermittent calf pain while walking that subsides with rest.

a PVC that falls between two sinus beats without effectively interrupting this rhythm.
the fluid in body tissues that is outside the cells and outside the vascular system.
an inflammation within the tissue surrounding the nephrons.
the space between cells.

cartilaginous pad between vertebrae that serves as a shock absorber.
the fluid inside the body cells.
bleeding directly into the tissue of the brain.
pressure exerted on the brain by the blood and cerebrospinal fluid.
resistant to cure, relief, or control.
within the dermal layer of the skin.
within the muscle.
within the bone.

the volume contained by all the arteries, veins and capillaries and other components of the circulatory system.

chemically prepared solution tailored to the body's specific needs.
passing a tube into a body opening.
condition that occurs when part of an intestine slips into the part just distal to itself.
consent to treatment granted by the authority of a court order.

a charged particle; an atom or group of atoms whose electrical charge has changed from neutral to positive or negative by losing or gaining one or more electrons. (In an atom's normal, non-ionized state, its positively charged protons and negatively charged electrons balance each other so that the atom's charge is neutral.)
the process of changing a substance into separate charged particles (ions).
to become electrically charged or polar.

electromagnetic radiation (e.g., x-ray) or particulate radiation (e.g., alpha particles, beta particles, and neutrons) that, by direct or secondary processes, ionizes materials that absorb the radiation. Ionizing radiation can penetrate the cells of living organisms, depositing an electrical charge within them. When sufficiently intense, this form of energy kills cells.
pigmented portion of the eye. It is the muscular area that constricts or dilates to change the size of the pupil.

also known as an incubator; a clear plastic enclosed bassinet used to keep prematurely born infants warm. The temperature of an isolette can be adjusted regardless of the room temperature. Some isolettes also provide humidity control.
active exercise performed against stable resistance, where muscles are exercised in a motionless manner.
the inability to concentrate or dilute urine relative to the osmolarity of blood.
equal in concentration of solute molecules; solutions may be isotonic to each other.

ECG deflection found at the junction of the QRS complex and the ST segment. It is associated with hypothermia and seen at core temperatures below 32° C, most commonly in leads II and V6; also called an Osborn wave.

an organ that produces urine and performs other functions related to the urinary system.
the energy an object has while it is in motion. It is related to the object's mass and velocity.
the branch of physics that deals with motion, taking into consideration mass, velocity, and force.

a plasma protein system that produces bradykinin, a substance that works with prostaglandins to cause pain. It also has actions similar to those of histamine (vasodilation and bronchospasm, increased permeability of the blood vessels, and chemotaxis) but acts more slowly than histamine, thus being more important during later stages of inflammation.
sounds of blood hitting arterial walls.

psychosis characterized by disorientation, muttering delirium, insomnia, delusions, and hallucinations. Symptoms include painful extremities, bilateral wrist drop (rarely), bilateral foot drop (frequently), and pain on pressure over the long nerves.
process of aerobic metabolism that uses carbohydrates, proteins, and fats to release energy for the body; also known as the citric acid cycle.

also called slow reacting substances of anaphylaxis (SRS-A); substances synthesized by mast cells during inflammatory response that cause vasoconstriction, vascular permeability, and chemotaxis.

the act of injuring a person's character, name, or reputation by false statements made in writing or through the mass media with malicious intent or reckless disregard for the falsity of those statements.

ligament that supports the duodenojejunal junction.
bands of connective tissue that connect bone to bone and hold joints together.
cord-like remnant of a fetal vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta at the aortic isthmus.
the process in which an alkali dissolves and liquefies tissue.
a legal document that allows a person to specify the kinds of medical treatment he wishes to receive should the need arise.
limited to one area of the body.
effects involving areas around the immediate site; should be evaluated based upon the burn model.
locking off of a machinery switch, then placing a tag on the switch stating why it is shut off; method of preventing equipment from being accidentally restarted.
supports incident operations, coordinating procurement and distribution of all medical resources.
bleeding in the gastrointestinal tract distal to the ligament of Treitz.

opening, or space, within a needle, artery, vein, or other hollow vessel.

scissor-style clamps with circular tips.

person who has suffered significant mechanism of injury.

the jawbone.

The aorta is usually dilated and may become weakened enough to allow an aneurysm to develop.
adherence of white cells to vessel walls in the early stages of inflammation.
a two-part auto-injector set the military uses as treatment for nerve-agent exposure; involves the administration of atropine and then pralidoxime chloride.
a device for protecting the face.
a measure of the matter that an object contains; the property of a physical body that gives the body inertia.

large cells, resembling bags of granules, that reside near blood vessels. When stimulated by injury, chemicals, or allergic responses, they activate the inflammatory response by degranulation (emptying their granules into the extracellular environment) and synthesis (construction of leukotrienes and prostaglandins).
easily accessible sheets of detailed information about chemicals found at fixed facilities.
continuing processes of wound reconstruction that may occur over a period of years after initial healing, as scar tissue is remodeled and strengthened.
bone of the upper jaw.
the theoretical, species-specific, longest duration of life, excluding premature or "unnatural" death.
common site of pain from appendicitis, one to two inches above the anterior iliac crest in a direct line with the umbilicus.
highly contagious, acute viral disease characterized by a reddish rash that appears on the fourth or fifth day of illness.

combined strength, direction, and nature of forces that injured your patient.
dark green material found in the intestine of the full-term newborn. It can be expelled from the intestine into the amniotic fluid during periods of fetal distress.

a physician who is legally responsible for all of the clinical and patient-care aspects of an EMS system. Also referred to as medical direction.

careful handling to prevent contamination.

lower portion of the brainstem, connecting the pons and the spinal cord. It contains major centers for control of respiratory, cardiac, and vasomotor activity.
cavity within a bone that contains the marrow.
dark, tarry, foul smelling stool indicating the presence of partially digested blood.
cells produced by mature B lymphocytes that "remember" the activating antigen and will trigger a stronger and swifter immune response if reexposure to the antigen occurs.
the onset of menses, usually occurring between ages 10 and 14.
a disease of the inner ear characterized by vertigo, nerve deafness, and a roar or buzzing in the ear.
membranes covering and protecting the brain and spinal cord. They consist of the pia mater, arachnoid membrane, and dura mater.

portion of the brain connecting the pons and cerebellum with the cerebral hemispheres; also called the midbrain. It controls motor coordination and eye movement.

abdominal pain associated with ovulation.
vehicle-mounted computer keyboard and display.
a procedure whereby a subject observes a model perform some behavior and then attempts to imitate that behavior. Many believe it is the fundamental learning process involved in socialization.

white cells with a single nucleus; the largest normal blood cells. During inflammation, monocytes mature and grow to several times their original size, becoming macrophages.

pervasive and sustained emotion that colors a person's perception of the world.
social, religious, or personal standards of right and wrong.

occurring when a newborn is startled, arms are thrown wide, fingers spread, and a grabbing motion follows. Also called startle reflex.
the process of changing place; movement.
medication intended to make mucus more watery.
lining in body cavities that handle air transport; usually contains small, mucus-secreting cells.
slippery secretion that lubricates and protects airway surfaces.

the cardiac muscle tissue of the heart.
temporary, involuntary twitching or spasm of a muscle or group of muscles.

word: National Emergency Crisis and Disasters Management Authority (NCEMA)
meaning: NCEMA operates under the Supervision of the Supreme Council for National Security, with the aim to achieve the UAE’s policy regarding the necessary procedures for emergency, crises and disasters management.
inborn protection against infection or disease that is part of the person's or species' genetic makeup.
immunity that begins to develop after birth and is continually enhanced by exposure to new pathogens and antigens throughout life.

cell death; a pathological cell change. Four types of necrotic cell change are coagulative, liquefactive, caseous, and fatty. Gangrenous necrosis refers to tissue death over a wide area.

a generalized disorder presenting a clinical picture of CNS hyperirritability, gastrointestinal dysfunction, respiratory distress, and vague autonomic symptoms. a baby in the first few hours of its life; also called a newly born infant.

excessive urination at night.

organisms that live inside our bodies without ordinarily causing disease.
